The iconic Icebergs Club pool at Bondi was drained on Thursday to serve as a unique catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia, specifically for a Ten Pieces presentation. The event featured a minimalist, unisex collection of ten monochrome outfits that can be styled in twenty different ways. Models walked through the empty pool and along the break wall, providing a backdrop of the ocean. Beachgoers and passersby were intrigued by the unusual spectacle, while guests enjoyed food and drinks from Icebergs and Santa Vittoria. The show took place on an unusually warm day with temperatures reaching 28 degrees Celsius.

Amir Khan, a Bolton-born boxer, spent a family day at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom, a safari park in Northern California, where he interacted with various animals including feeding a rare white tiger and posing with giraffes and sea lions. Accompanying him were his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and their daughter Lamysa. Additionally, Khan announced he would be fighting Chris Algieri, a former light-welterweight world champion, on May 30th.

The passage describes the removal of Palestinian teenager Mohammed Abu Khdeir's name from an Israeli memorial wall that honors fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism. His name was initially included due to the upcoming memorial day but was later removed after his family and the organization Almagor protested, arguing that his death was a result of a rogue attack rather than terrorism. The incident occurred when Abu Khdeir, 16, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July. The National Insurance Institute of Israel agreed to remove his name following complaints.

The passage describes a YouTube video where a young boy attempts to use his cat as a pillow while playing in the garden. The cat, initially sitting and grooming itself, has the boy sit on it, but quickly moves away each time the boy tries to rest. This chase repeats until the cat gives up and goes inside. Later, the boy feeds the cat treats, indicating they have reconciled.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia involves testimony from former drug dealers, including Robert Kushner, who lost his coaching job after revealing his past involvement in drug sales. Kushner testified about officers stealing from him during an arrest in 2007. Despite passing a background check, his criminal history became known to his employer, Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy, leading to his dismissal. The defense claims the prosecution's case relies on dishonest witnesses.

The passage describes an explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou City, Fujian Province, China, which produced paraxylene (PX), a potentially carcinogenic substance used in polyester production. The incident caused a fire and injured six people, five of whom were hurt by broken glass. Over 600 firefighters controlled the blaze. No toxic chemical spill was reported. The plant previously experienced another explosion in July 2013 without casualties or toxic leaks. PX plant constructions have led to protests across China due to pollution fears. The Zhangzhou plant was initially planned for Xiamen but was moved to its current site due to public opposition in 2007.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa player and Ireland Under 21 international, is known for his unique style of wearing his socks very low, just above his shinpads, which he insists on doing due to superstition. Despite some referees' attempts to persuade him otherwise, Grealish continues this practice, even during his first Premier League start against QPR, where he wore children's-sized shinpads underneath. He expressed satisfaction with getting his first start despite the challenging nature of the match, acknowledging the manager's faith in him and hoping for more opportunities before the season ends.

The passage discusses Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, who is reported to have "global and irreversible brain damage." Despite being taken out of a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive. Her grandmother, Cissy Houston, expressed sadness over the possibility of her living in this condition for a lifetime. There's a discrepancy between the family's optimistic statements and medical sources indicating no significant improvement in her neurological state. She does not respond to visitors or familiar voices and has a tracheostomy. An attorney for the family stated that while she will have a long life, the quality of her life post-rehabilitation remains uncertain.

Russia is on the verge of reaching the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead over Germany. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova secured a victory against Sabine Lisicki despite saving a match point, winning 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3. Svetlana Kuznetsova also contributed to Russia's lead by beating Julia Goerges in straight sets. Both players struggled with their serves; Pavlyuchenkova made 13 double faults while Lisicki had 63 unforced errors. With this score, Russia needs just one more win from Sunday's matches to secure a spot in the final and potentially claim their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

The passage describes warnings for residents of New South Wales, Australia, who are facing potential additional floods and damage due to another storm predicted to hit later in the week. This follows severe weather from the previous week that caused extensive flooding and damage. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that new storms could hinder ongoing cleanup efforts, particularly in the Hunter region which was heavily affected. Meteorologists predict an East Coast Low weather system similar to the one from last week, potentially bringing heavy rain from Thursday to Saturday, though possibly less severe and affecting different areas. The SES is urging communities to prepare for further weather impacts.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" music video, denied reports that she attempted suicide. She clarified that she was hospitalized after collapsing due to low blood pressure and not from a suicide attempt. Despite this, Italian media reported conflicting accounts, including statements from her boyfriend suggesting she had tried to commit suicide. Moric shared images of her injuries on Instagram and assured her followers that she was recovering at home. The incident revived old claims about her past suicide attempts, including one in 2009. Additionally, the passage mentions her previous marriage to paparazzo Fabrizio Corona, who served time for blackmailing celebrities.

The passage discusses a public poll conducted by YouGov for The Sunday Times regarding the preferred names for the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge's second child. Diana is the most favored name for a girl, honoring William's mother, Princess Diana. Alice and Charlotte follow closely behind. For a boy, James and Alexander are the top choices. Many Brits hope for a girl, with 25% of those polled expressing this wish. Additionally, the majority supports William's plan to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 and injuring 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The attack occurred as the protesters were heading to a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group has claimed it. The explosion happened at around 10 a.m. local time.

Dani Alves, the Brazilian right-back, is likely to leave Barcelona this summer as he has rejected the club's final contract offer. Despite enjoying seven successful years at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies, Alves could not agree on a new deal with the Catalan club. His agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, announced at a press conference that negotiations were over due to the club's final offer being contingent upon Alves playing in 60% of matches, which she found unreasonable.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old soccer player who recently joined Boca Juniors on loan from Southampton, is advocating for Italian soccer legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at his new club. Osvaldo believes these players, known for their exceptional skills and popularity, would fit well into the South American style of play and would be warmly welcomed by Boca Juniors' fans. He considers Pirlo and Totti to be among the greatest players he has played alongside and emphasizes their potential impact on the team and fanbase.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, experienced a dramatic double somersault fall from his horse Merrion Square during a race at Wincanton. Despite the fall making him an internet sensation with hundreds of thousands of views, he only sustained a minor injury—a cut on his nose. At Paul Nicholls' yard, Ferguson continued his routine duties without any special treatment. He expressed that the incident was unexpected and that fellow jockeys showed concern for his well-being. Reflecting on the event, Ferguson humorously considered pursuing a gymnastics career post-racing.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain, celebrated the release of "Avengers: Age of Ultron" by posting an Instagram picture of himself dressed as Iron Man. The movie premiered at Westfield London Shopping Centre, attracting fans and A-list actors like Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, and Scarlett Johansson. Haskell's post included a message about releasing his inner Iron Man. Additionally, the passage provides details about Haskell's rugby career, including his time abroad playing for Stade Français, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders, before returning to Wasps in 2012, where he has since surpassed 100 appearances and become a significant player for both Wasps and England's national team.

The passage discusses the rise of wide leg trousers as a prominent fashion trend for Spring/Summer 2015, offering an alternative to the enduring popularity of skinny jeans. It highlights the versatility of wide leg trousers, which can be styled in various ways such as cropped, printed, or striped, and suggests pairing them with high-heeled shoes and simple tops to maintain balance and elegance. The trend draws inspiration from the 1970s and has been featured by designers like Gucci, Celine, and Stella McCartney. Retailers like Topshop and new labels like Finery London offer affordable options for those looking to adopt this trend.

The University of Michigan decided to screen the film "American Sniper" despite objections from over 200 students who signed a petition against it due to its negative depiction of the Iraq War and concerns about Middle Eastern representation. The film's screening was initially canceled but then reinstated after a backlash and a counter-petition. The university emphasized the importance of freedom of expression and the right of students to choose what they watch. As an alternative, UMIX, a series of social events, will also screen the family-friendly film "Paddington."

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, were charged with animal cruelty after attempting to set a quokka on fire on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka, which resembles a domestic cat, was only singed. The tourists were questioned by detectives, had video evidence seized, and were evicted from the island. They will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17. Quokkas are native to small islands off the West Australian coast, particularly Rottnest Island and Bald Island.

The passage describes how filmmakers helped 102-year-old Alice Barker, who was a dancer in New York nightclubs during the 1930s and 1940s, see footage of herself dancing for the first time. Her memorabilia and photos had been lost, so Mark Cantor and volunteers compiled a video of "soundies," early music videos, which they showed to Barker at her nursing home. She was very pleased to see herself dancing again.

The passage discusses the declining trend of individuals washing their own cars in Britain, particularly among men where a third admit to never having done so. Women are even less likely to wash their own cars, with three-quarters never doing it. The study, conducted by vehicle leasing firm OSV, surveyed 1,100 adults and found that only 12% of men who wash their cars do it regularly. Reasons for this shift include increased Sunday shopping availability, more live sports on TV, the rise of hand car wash services, and the difficulty in cleaning larger vehicles like 4x4s. However, car washing peaks during holidays, such as Easter, when an estimated 15 million cars were cleaned by their owners. This activity is most common in cities like Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, while least common in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Certain car brands, like Audis, Toyotas, and BMWs, are more frequently washed by their owners compared to Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes.

The passage discusses Martin Skrtel's praise for Steven Gerrard's influence since Gerrard's arrival at Liverpool in 2008. Skrtel acknowledges Gerrard's significant impact on him personally and believes Liverpool can find suitable replacements for Gerrard, who is set to leave the club after the FA Cup final on May 30th. Gerrard aims to lead Liverpool into the FA Cup final against Arsenal on his birthday, having already led them past Aston Villa in the semi-final. Skrtel highlights Gerrard's leadership qualities and his importance to Liverpool, while also expressing optimism about the future despite the challenges of filling Gerrard's role.

At the age of 75, Jack Nicklaus achieved a hole in one during the Par-3 contest at Augusta National, impressing the crowd. He played alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. This event occurred amidst Masters Week activities. Nicklaus's achievement was part of a day where five aces were hit, tying the record set in 2002. Camilo Villegas also made two holes in one but did not win the contest, which was eventually won by Kevin Streelman in a playoff. Nicklaus has a rich history at Augusta, having won six Green Jackets and being one of only five players to complete the career grand slam.

The passage describes severe weather conditions affecting multiple states, primarily focusing on Kansas and Missouri. In Kansas, tornado warnings sounded as several storms swept through, with confirmed sightings near Goddard and Aetna. These tornadoes posed risks throughout the night. Meanwhile, in Missouri, a possible tornado hit Potosi, causing wind damage and flooding. Additional reports included large hail in nearby areas. Weather experts warn that nighttime tornadoes are particularly dangerous. Further severe weather is anticipated for Thursday across parts of the Midwest and surrounding regions.

An Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter charges after allegedly accidentally shooting Eric Harris with a gun instead of a taser during a weapons sting operation. The judge allowed Bates to take a family vacation to the Bahamas, which upset Harris' family. Bates' preliminary hearing is set for July 2nd. There are allegations that Bates was unqualified for his position due to preferential treatment from the sheriff, though the sheriff's office denies these claims. Two deputies involved in Harris' arrest have been reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor, preparing for a featherweight title fight against Jose Aldo on July 11, has shown off a new tiger tattoo on his stomach alongside an existing gorilla tattoo on his chest. McGregor claims Aldo lacks the same level of motivation he possesses for the upcoming match, which will be Aldo's eighth defense of the featherweight title. The two fighters have a tense relationship, highlighted by an incident during a promotional tour where McGregor took Aldo's belt in front of 5,000 supporters in Dublin.

Tony Abbott, the Australian Prime Minister, faced criticism for drinking a schooner of beer in less than six seconds at an Australian Rules function, which some view as promoting binge drinking and linking masculinity with alcohol consumption. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert criticized Abbott for not advocating against excessive drinking, instead showcasing his masculinity through the act. The incident sparked debate over whether such behavior glorifies irresponsible drinking and reinforces stereotypes about Australian culture. Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott's actions, suggesting that his fitness routine and public displays like these could contribute to a healthier lifestyle. Critics argue that as a leader, Abbott should set a better example regarding responsible drinking.

The passage describes a significant increase in HIV cases in Scott County, Indiana, linked to intravenous drug use, particularly involving the painkiller Opana. There are now 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positives, up from 106 the previous week. Governor Mike Pence approved a 30-day needle exchange program in response to the outbreak, which has distributed over 5,000 clean syringes. The program's future, along with broader legislation allowing needle exchanges in other high-risk counties, remains uncertain due to concerns about promoting drug use. Lawmakers debate the effectiveness and sustainability of such programs amid federal funding bans.

The passage describes a situation where an Arsenal Football Club fan created an extensive and detailed quiz for his girlfriend, Saskia, testing her knowledge about the club. The quiz included various types of questions such as multiple-choice, fill-in-the-blank, and subjective questions. Saskia scored 87%, impressing her boyfriend enough to avoid being "dumped." She faced challenges in naming the entire starting eleven squad and understanding player positions correctly. Her boyfriend marked her answers strictly, providing corrections and additional comments, especially when she got something wrong. Despite the strictness, Saskia's performance was deemed satisfactory, earning her an 'A' grade. The incident garnered mixed reactions online, with some praising the boyfriend's dedication and others finding the situation excessive.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, has worked as an undercover DEA operative for 27 years in exchange for U.S. citizenship. He fled Colombia in the 1980s due to a conflict with his boss and provided crucial information leading to the arrest of several high-profile figures including Carlos Lehder Rivas and Manuel Noriega. Despite his contributions, Toro faces deportation as he never received citizenship and is now living in the U.S. illegally due to declining health which forced his retirement. The DEA declined to assist him with his citizenship application, leaving him fearful of returning to Colombia where he believes he would face immediate danger.

A 14-year-old girl from Kosi Kalan, India, was allegedly gang-raped and, subsequently, set herself on fire with kerosene, suffering 70% burns. She is hospitalized in Safdarjung Hospital, Delhi. The incident occurred when she went outside her house to relieve herself. Her family reportedly advised her to remain silent about the attack. Five suspects have been apprehended. This event highlights the ongoing issues of sexual assault in India, which have spurred public outrage and calls for better protection for women. Recent cases have led to widespread protests and instances of vigilante justice.

Louis van Gaal, Manchester United's manager, expresses his desire to beat Manchester City in Sunday's derby at Old Trafford despite ruling out Robin van Persie due to fitness concerns. Van Gaal emphasizes the importance of controlling aggression during the match. With City struggling after a recent defeat, United has an opportunity to secure a top-three finish and avoid a Champions League qualifying round. Van Gaal also confirms Luke Shaw is unfit to play. The manager appreciates the support from Manchester United fans and looks forward to experiencing the derby atmosphere.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against escalating ticket prices during their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium by leaving their seats empty for the first ten minutes. The protest was spurred by the recent £5.14 billion TV rights deal and ticket prices starting at £64. Fans displayed banners criticizing the high costs and expressing frustration over the perceived prioritization of profit over the fan experience. The protest aimed to highlight the financial strain on supporters and呼吁球迷团结起来对抗票价上涨的问题。球迷们在外围展示了一个标语，上面写着“没有球迷的足球什么都不是”。组织者希望看到实质性的票价降低，并警告如果不采取行动可能会失去整整一代球迷。比赛结束后预计会有进一步的抗议活动。

A newborn named Star, diagnosed with biliary atresia shortly after birth in Barnsley, West Yorkshire, required a liver transplant to survive. Neither of her parents were suitable donors, but her maternal aunt, Shanell Reader (twin sister of Star's mother), donated part of her liver. The transplant was successful, and Star has since made a good recovery, though she will require ongoing medical care. Biliary atresia is a rare condition affecting bile ducts, which can be fatal if untreated.

The passage describes Chelsea Football Club players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participating in Audi's Football Challenge. The event included several rounds: sinking balls into the boot of a car from close range, playing over an Audi R8 V10 Plus acting as a tennis net, and shooting footballs from long range into convertibles. Hazard and Ake initially led, but Remy and Willian secured a surprising victory in the final round, despite Willian accidentally damaging a car's wing mirror.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, caused a fatal highway crash in December 2013 that killed a Vermont couple, Jason Timmons and Amanda Murphy, along with their unborn child. Initially, Dellinger told investigators he was attempting suicide, but during his sentencing, he denied this claim. He pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault charges related to the incident. Dellinger's defense team argued that he was experiencing side effects from medication and suffering from multiple sclerosis at the time of the crash. The judge is set to sentence him to between 12 to 24 years in prison. Additionally, Dellinger faces a wrongful death lawsuit filed by Amanda Murphy's estate.

The passage describes the sentencing of Lacey Spears, who was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son Garnett-Paul Spears with salt. She received a sentence of 20 years to life in prison, sparing her the maximum 25 years to life. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed anger on Facebook, hoping for harsh treatment of Spears in prison due to her lack of emotion during the sentencing. Prosecutors argued that Spears poisoned her son to gain attention, while her lawyer claimed she was innocent and planned to appeal the verdict. The case highlights Spears' use of her son's medical issues for personal gain, leading to his death.

The passage discusses the arrival of an improved influenza vaccine in Australia due to a mismatch between the previous vaccine and two new strains of influenza (H3N2 and B/Phuket) that led to increased flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States. The new vaccine includes protection against these strains and is expected to better match global circulating strains. High-risk groups can access free government-funded flu shots from April 20th. Experts recommend early booking of flu shots despite the stock delay, emphasizing the importance of protecting both high-risk individuals and those around them.

The passage discusses the challenges faced by Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois, including criticism from National Geographic and potential budget cuts that could affect its management. The state, facing financial difficulties, proposes merging the Historic Preservation Agency, which oversees the tomb, into another department. Despite these issues, the tomb remains a significant tourist attraction and underwent substantial renovations recently. However, some visitors and local supporters argue against the negative portrayal of the site, emphasizing its historical importance and aesthetic appeal.

The passage discusses the resurgence of various fashion trends from the 1990s and early 2000s, including chokers, berry-colored lips, round sunglasses, Calvin Klein logo t-shirts, and JNCO jeans, while also highlighting specific items like bucket hats, camouflage prints, extreme trends (such as designer prints and double denim), UGG boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outfits, and harem trousers. The article contrasts how these trends were worn in their heyday with how they are currently being revived by contemporary celebrities and fashion enthusiasts.

The passage summarizes a week's worth of trending stories from various parts of the world. Key highlights include: four rainbows appearing over New York; a Chinese government crackdown on exotic dancers at funerals; Robert Downey Jr.'s frustration during an interview; the Kardashian family's influence on a new lip-plumping trend; a 102-year-old woman experiencing a time travel adventure; controversy over a racially charged prom proposal; casting news for "Beauty and the Beast"; Johnny Depp's appearance in the "Black Mass" trailer; a creative pregnancy announcement referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a father photobombing his son's picture.

The passage describes Serena Williams achieving her 700th career victory at the Miami Open, which is celebrated with a large cake. She won her match against Sabine Lisicki in three sets and advanced to the semi-finals. Despite her sister Venus being eliminated earlier, Serena aims to stay competitive in this event close to her hometown. The article also mentions Andy Murray's recent 500th win, similarly celebrated with a cake. In the semi-finals, Serena will play Simona Halep, who defeated Sloane Stephens in her match.

Sabeen Mahmud, who ran a second-floor cafe in Karachi, Pakistan, was killed by two gunmen after locking up her establishment. The cafe served as a hub for discussions on technology, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship. Her murder highlights the dangers of free speech in Pakistan; she was known for openly discussing controversial topics such as the situation in Baluchistan. No one has claimed responsibility for her shooting, and her death has sparked grief and appreciation for her work promoting non-violence and progressive values.

The passage describes Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu traditional healer living in Indian Kashmir, who fled to the region as a refugee following the partition of India in 1947. Despite spending nearly 70 years in Kashmir, Ram and other West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) remain without citizenship rights, unable to own property or vote in state elections. This situation affects approximately 100,000 WPRs, primarily Hindus from Punjab, who have been denied residential rights due to fears of altering the demographic balance in India's Muslim-majority Kashmir. However, there is renewed hope for change following the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party's (BJP) recent electoral gains in the region.

Yoshinori Muto, FC Tokyo's forward, is contemplating a move to Chelsea, Premier League leaders, this summer. Chelsea reportedly offered around £4 million for Muto, planning to loan him to Vitesse Arnhem initially. However, Muto seeks a club where he can play regularly and develop further. Real Zaragoza's coach, Ranko Popovic, praises Muto's intelligence, speed, strength, and confidence. Chelsea's Jose Mourinho acknowledges knowing about Muto but emphasizes that any signing must align with the club's financial policies and the player's quality.

The passage discusses Australia's decision to drop a policy that prevented the selection of players based on their location, allowing for the inclusion of top-performing overseas players in national teams. This move is seen as progressive compared to England's stance, which restricts selection to players within English clubs. The author argues that this policy change enhances team performance and fairness, using examples like Matt Giteau and Steffon Armitage, whose performances have improved after moving overseas. The discussion emphasizes the importance of selecting the best players for major tournaments like the World Cup, regardless of their club locations, to ensure competitiveness and success.

The passage describes FireChat, an app allowing users to chat without internet or mobile signals through wireless mesh networks. Open Garden developed Greenstone, an egg-shaped device acting as a beacon or booster to enhance these networks' strength and extend their reach. FireChat leverages Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) and Android's similar Bluetooth feature to create localized networks where phones act as nodes passing data. Greenstone aims to overcome limitations in message transmission distance, enabling broader communication resilience in various settings including events prone to network congestion.

The passage describes Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, who advocates for the acceptance of the term "fat" as a positive and honest descriptor of her body. During a TED Talk, she emphasizes that words like "short," "wife," and "fat" are merely factual descriptions without negative connotations. She highlights societal pressures, particularly among young girls, to be thin and notes that size discrimination in workplaces has increased. However, she cites studies suggesting increased exposure to diverse body types fosters tolerance and preference for varied body shapes. Lillian performs burlesque to positively showcase larger bodies and inspire others to embrace their bodies confidently. Her TED Talk, posted on YouTube, garnered widespread positive feedback despite some negative comments.

Theo Walcott, along with several Arsenal teammates including Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil, participated in a photoshoot for the Parisian fashion house Lanvin. This comes amid Walcott's reduced playing time this season; he has been named on the substitutes' bench for 17 out of 33 Premier League games. Despite this, Walcott hopes to secure a starting position for Arsenal's upcoming match against Hull City.

The passage describes an auction event where a collection of movie props and puppets, created by renowned makeup effects artist Rick Baker, will be sold. The auction, taking place on May 29th both in person at Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online via PropStore.com, features over 400 items from more than 50 film productions. Notable items include the Alien Edgar Bug from "Men in Black" (estimated at $40,000), Batman's Two-Face Mask from "Batman Forever" ($1,500), and the Grinch costume from "How the Grinch Stole Christmas" ($8,000). The entire collection is estimated to be worth around $746,100. Baker's career highlights include works on films such as "American Werewolf in London," "Planet of the Apes," and "Hellboy."

The passage describes the tragic death of Carwyn Scott-Howell, a seven-year-old British boy who fell to his death while skiing in the French Alps. He became separated from his family during their last run of the day and ventured into dense woodland, likely drawn by the sight of the ski resort below. His mother, Ceri, and sister, Antonia, initially did not notice his absence until later. The family expressed deep sorrow, describing Carwyn as a "daring, outgoing, and determined" child who brought joy and laughter wherever he went. Police found his body via footprints leading to a 164-foot drop. The community mourned his loss, and plans were made for his repatriation.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia at age 13 due to pressure to achieve a 'size zero' figure. She survived on minimal food, lied to her mother about eating, and hid food. Her condition worsened to the point where she collapsed from starvation and was placed on a heart machine in intensive care. Laura attributes her obsession with weight to bullying and societal pressures. After a week in the hospital, she received support from eating disorder organizations and began her recovery process. Now, she participates in Miss Teen GB to promote positive body image and confidence among young girls.

The passage describes the unveiling of Liverpool FC's new home kit for the 2015/16 season by players including Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet at Anfield. The new gingham design, sponsored by New Balance under a £300 million deal, replaces Warrior as the club's supplier. During the event, Liverpool supporters expressed their desire for Sterling to stay at the club despite recent speculation about his future due to his rejection of a new contract. The players also discussed their upcoming FA Cup semi-final match against Aston Villa.

The passage describes the creation of the largest single high-definition map of dark matter, which covers 0.4% of the sky and is part of a larger project aiming to map 12.5% of the sky over five years. This map, produced by University of Manchester researchers, uses data from the Dark Energy Camera to study the distribution of dark matter and its influence on galaxy formation. The map employs gravitational lensing to detect dark matter's presence, showing clumps of dark matter across the observed area. The ultimate goal of the Dark Energy Survey is to create a 3D map of dark matter and dark energy, aiding in understanding the universe's structure and the nature of dark energy.

Manchester United has intensified its pursuit of PSV Eindhoven's Memphis Depay by making an official approach for the 21-year-old player. Louis van Gaal, Manchester United's manager and the coach who included Depay in the Netherlands' World Cup squad, is eager to secure Depay as one of his key summer signings. Depay, known for his dribbling skills and ability to score from distance, has had a standout season with PSV, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games. Despite interest from other clubs, including Paris Saint-Germain, Manchester United seems to be in a favorable position to sign Depay, who has been praised for his potential to match or surpass the quality of players like Arjen Robben and Cristiano Ronaldo.

Chelsea secured a strong 3-1 lead against Manchester City's youth team in the first leg of their match, played at the Academy Stadium in Manchester. Tammy Abraham scored twice in the first half, while Dominic Solanke added a goal late in the game. Despite Manchester City's efforts, including Isaac Buckley-Ricketts equalizing once, Chelsea's defense, led by Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter, managed to hold off the City attack. The passage also provides detailed analysis of individual performances from both teams.

The passage summarizes Marco Rubio's stance on same-sex marriage and sexual orientation during his presidential campaign. Rubio claims that people are born with their sexual preferences and acknowledges attending a same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer despite personal disagreement. He argues that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman and believes states, not courts, should regulate marriage definitions through political debates. Additionally, Rubio has received significant financial support for his campaign.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish and Latvian couple respectively, embarked on a bicycle journey around the world after quitting their jobs in Manchester. They aim to explore different parts of the planet leisurely and economically. Since starting their adventure from London nearly a year ago, they've traveled through 16 countries, covering almost 7,000 miles. Living frugally, they spend less than €3 per day each, mostly on food, and rely on camping, Couchsurfing, and Warmshowers for accommodation. Their route has taken them through Western Europe, the Balkans, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, with plans to continue into Asia and eventually cross the Pacific.

A Texas couple who got married in 2012 is suing their wedding photographer, James Evans of Premiere Photos, for allegedly printing racial slurs on the bottom of photo booth snapshots from their event. The couple only found out about the incident months later. They hired attorney Cathy Hale to represent them under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence and breach of contract. James Evans denies the allegations and reportedly told the couple to sue him. The couple seeks an apology rather than monetary compensation. Mediation is scheduled to resolve the issue before the case goes to trial in July.

The passage discusses Mike Brown's cautious approach to recovery from a concussion, emphasizing the importance of not rushing back to avoid prolonged absences similar to Johnny Sexton's 12-week stand-down. Brown highlights increased awareness of concussion symptoms due to World Rugby online modules, which influenced his decision to pull out of matches despite their significance. Additionally, George North is mentioned as being advised not to play for the rest of the season after suffering four quick-fire concussions. The text underscores the seriousness of managing concussions to prevent long-term health issues.

The passage discusses a potential link between smartphone and internet usage and a decrease in sexual activity among British couples. According to Professor David Spiegelhalter from Cambridge University, the average frequency of sexual intercourse for a typical heterosexual couple has dropped to three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. The decline is attributed to increased connectivity and integration of personal and professional life due to technology, leading to less private time and more competing demands on individuals' time, causing sex to fall lower on their priority list.

The passage describes the drastic fall in popularity of Tibetan Mastiffs in China, once highly valued and priced up to £1.2 million each, due to government anti-corruption measures and urbanization challenges. These factors have led to a surplus of these dogs, many of which are now being sent to slaughterhouses. The dogs' decline is also attributed to breeding practices that compromised their quality and to new regulations limiting large dog ownership in major cities. This situation has resulted in inhumane treatment of the dogs, with some being found dead or injured during transport to slaughterhouses.

The passage discusses a survey conducted in Paris where every woman surveyed reported experiencing some form of sexual harassment on public transport, with half of them having faced such harassment before the age of 18. The survey highlights that harassment ranges from verbal insults and inappropriate behavior to more severe forms like sexual assault or rape. It also notes that this issue causes significant fear among women, leading many to alter their routines to avoid potential confrontations. The findings prompted calls for campaigns against sexist and threatening behaviors on public transport, emphasizing the need for women to feel safe in public spaces. Additionally, there's an emphasis on educating both victims and perpetrators about the legal consequences of such actions.

The passage describes a competition called #EverydayFix by Direct Line, where groups were tasked with designing products to solve common daily problems identified in a survey of 2,000 people. The top issues included not being able to sleep, losing keys, and running out of phone battery. Three prototypes made it to the final shortlist: Snooze (an alarm clock that silences notifications), Forget Me Lock (a key device indicating if a door is locked), and Nipper (a tiny phone charger using household batteries). People can vote for their favorite via Twitter, and the winning product will enter a Kickstarter campaign for production.

Vera Baird, the Police and Crime Commissioner for Northumbria, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice for allocating over £500,000 of public funds to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she directs. Sue Sim, the Northumbria's Chief Constable and also a director of the charity, sits alongside her. Critics argue this arrangement constitutes a conflict of interest and misuse of public funds. Keith Vaz, Labour chairman of the Home Affairs Committee, described the situation as "a soap opera" and inappropriate. The Ministry of Justice will investigate whether conflict of interest rules were violated.

Three individuals have been imprisoned and two more await sentencing for their involvement in a brutal assault on Greg Valecce, a 53-year-old man. The attack, orchestrated by Corey Campbell, referred to as the "tattoo terrorists" leader, included beating, tying Valecce to a chair, and forcibly tattooing him with offensive designs. This occurred after Campbell suspected Valecce of harming his cat and stealing from him. The assault lasted approximately 42 hours in Mayfair, Philadelphia. Campbell received a 20-year sentence, while his girlfriend Sandra Ng got 23 months. Carl Halin also received a 20-year sentence. The victims' injuries included broken ribs, wrists, and facial fractures.

Manchester United has intensified its pursuit of PSV Eindhoven's Memphis Depay by making an official bid for the 21-year-old player. Louis van Gaal, Manchester United's manager and the coach who included Depay in the Netherlands' World Cup squad, is eager to secure Depay as one of his key summer signings. Depay, known for his dribbling skills and ability to score from distance, has had a standout season with PSV, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games. Despite interest from other clubs, including Paris Saint-Germain, Manchester United seems to be in a favorable position to sign Depay, who has been compared favorably to Cristiano Ronaldo and Arjen Robben by scouts and managers alike.

Qatar Airways, based in Doha with its headquarters in the Qatar Airways Tower, operates from Hamad International Airport. It uses a hub-and-spoke network to connect over 160 destinations across various continents with a fleet exceeding 200 aircraft.

Maxthon is reported to be the second most popular browser in China and has achieved over 500 million downloads globally.
